items.title: Netanyahu reverses course, accepts Trump Board of Peace invite

featured_image.name: Israel's Netanyahu to join ‘Board of Peace'

items.description:
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced Wednesday that he has agreed to join U.S. President Donald Trump's Board of Peace, reversing course just days after his office criticized the initiative's leadership structure for including Turkey and Qatar without Israel's consultation.

"Prime Minister Netanyahu announced that he has accepted US President Donald Trump's invitation and will join as a member of the Board of Peace, which will be composed of leaders of the world," his office stated on social media. The decision sets up a potential clash with far-right coalition partners who have condemned Trump's Gaza governance framework.[1][2]

items.title: Trump, NATO chief announce Greenland deal framework at Davos

featured_image.name: Trump opens Davos remarks, saying he's brought 'phenomenal' US ...

items.description:
President Donald Trump announced Wednesday that he and NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte have formed "the framework of a future deal with respect to Greenland and, in fact, the entire Arctic Region," marking a potential de-escalation of tensions that have strained transatlantic relations for weeks.

The announcement came after Trump addressed the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, where he ruled out using military force to acquire Greenland for the first time since his push to acquire the Danish territory intensified. "I don't have to use force. I don't want to use force. I won't use force," Trump declared during his speech.[1][2][3]

items.title: Trump says he and NATO chief reached framework on Greenland

featured_image.name: Trump live news: US president says 'framework' reached for ...

items.description:
At a World Economic Forum panel in Davos on Wednesday, NATO's top officials delivered a unified message: despite U.S. President Donald Trump's aggressive push to acquire Greenland, Ukraine's defense against Russian aggression must remain the alliance's primary focus.

NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte, speaking alongside Polish President Karol Nawrocki and Finnish President Alexander Stubb during a panel titled "Can Europe Defend Itself?", warned against allowing the Greenland dispute to overshadow the war in Ukraine.[1][2][3]

On Greenland, "we have to make sure that that issue gets solved in an amicable way,” Rutte said. “But the main issue is not Greenland now, the main issue is Ukraine,” he added, warning that leaders risk “dropping the ball” by focusing too much on Greenland instead of Ukraine.[2][1]

items.title: Kremlin contradicts Trump's claim that Putin accepted Board of Peace invite

featured_image.name: Kremlin says Trump invited Putin to join 'Board of Peace ...

items.description: President Donald Trump claimed Wednesday that Russian President Vladimir Putin had agreed to join his Board of Peace initiative, only for the Kremlin to swiftly contradict him, stating Moscow was still evaluating the offer. The dispute unfolded at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, casting a spotlight on the controversial invitations to leaders facing international war crimes charges.

items.title: Live: Nationals split Coalition, Littleproud blames Ley for 'untenable' position
items.description: After quitting the shadow ministry en masse in solidarity with three colleagues dumped for crossing the floor on hate laws, Nationals leader David Littleproud says the Coalition has been forced into an "untenable position that can no longer continue". Follow live.

items.title: Trump rules out force for Greenland, demands negotiations

featured_image.name: Trump says no nation can secure Greenland but the US in Davos speech

items.description:
President Donald Trump delivered a defiant 72-minute speech at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland on Wednesday, ruling out military force to acquire Greenland while demanding "immediate negotiations" with Denmark over the Arctic territory and criticizing European allies as heading in the "wrong direction."

The address, widely anticipated as a pivotal moment in escalating transatlantic tensions, saw Trump claim Greenland as American territory while simultaneously attempting to reassure nervous European partners. "We probably won't get anything unless I decide to use excessive strength and force, where we would be, frankly, unstoppable. But I won't do that," Trump told the audience of billionaires, government officials, and diplomats.[1][2]

items.title: Trump rules out military force in Greenland bid at Davos

featured_image.name: Stock markets rebound after Trump's Davos speech on Greenland

items.description:
President Donald Trump told a gathering of global elites at the World Economic Forum on Wednesday that he would not deploy military force to take control of Greenland, easing fears of a transatlantic crisis that triggered Wall Street's steepest selloff in three months just one day earlier.

"I don't have to use force. I don't want to use force. I won't use force," Trump declared in his keynote address in Davos, Switzerland, adding that "people thought I would use force" and calling his pledge "probably the biggest statement I made." While ruling out military action, Trump called for "immediate negotiations" with Denmark to transfer ownership of the Arctic territory.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: Trump delays tariffs on European allies after NATO deal on Greenland

featured_image.name: Trump in Davos says NATO should allow the US to take ...

items.description:
President Donald Trump announced Wednesday he will hold off on imposing tariffs on eight European nations after reaching what he called "the framework of a future deal" with NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte regarding Greenland and the Arctic region.

The surprise announcement came just hours after Trump used his address at the World Economic Forum in Davos to reiterate demands for "immediate negotiations" on the United States acquiring the Danish territory, marking a dramatic de-escalation in a dispute that had rattled transatlantic relations for weeks.

items.title: Five quick hits: Sinner weighs up Kyrgios vs Kim and an Aussie exodus
items.description: Jannik Sinner was stuck in an awkward moment discussing Nick Kyrgios and Kim Jong-Un while Coco Gauff shared her top artists. Here are the quick hits from the Australian Open.

items.title: 'Ten-pound Pom' vows to boycott UK over 'money grab' passport changes
items.description: People who came to Australia as children from the UK as part of an organised migration scheme say they the UK's new regulations for dual citizens unfairly targets them.

items.title: Denmark rejects Greenland talks after Trump rules out military force

featured_image.name: Trump updates: Danish FM says Denmark, US still ‘differ’ over Greenland

items.description:
Denmark on Wednesday rejected any deal or talks to transfer its sovereignty over Greenland to the United States, hours after President Donald Trump called for "immediate negotiations" on acquiring the Arctic territory but ruled out using military force during his speech at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

Danish Prime Minister Lars Løkke Rasmussen welcomed Trump's statement that he would not use force but made clear that the issue was far from resolved. "It is positive that it is being said that military force will not be used. But that will not make this case go away," Rasmussen said following a meeting of the Foreign Policy Committee in Copenhagen, according to public broadcaster TV2.[1]

items.title: US envoys to meet Putin Thursday as Ukraine peace talks advance

featured_image.name: US, Russia envoys meet in Davos as Ukraine reconstruction plan postponed

items.description:
Russian President Vladimir Putin received an early draft of the U.S.-backed peace plan for Ukraine in early January through Kirill Dmitriev, head of the Russian Direct Investment Fund, according to a report by Bloomberg. The plan, which had been coordinated with Ukrainian and European partners, was delivered informally to give the Kremlin time to review the proposal and prepare feedback before expected high-level talks.[1][2]

The diplomatic maneuver comes as U.S. Special Envoy Steve Witkoff confirmed Wednesday that he and Jared Kushner, President Donald Trump's son-in-law, will travel to Moscow on Thursday to meet with Putin. "The Russians are the ones requesting this meeting. I believe this is a noteworthy indication on their part," Witkoff said at the World Economic Forum in Davos.[3][4][5][6]

items.title: Debt is America's Achilles heel in a fracturing world order
items.description: For decades, global investors have bought US government debt as a safe haven when things turn pear-shaped. But investor attitudes are changing, and America's financial domination is at stake.

items.title: Australia earns global praise for economic 'soft landing'
items.description: A new report from the OECD says Australia's economy is returning to normal but remains vulnerable and lacks dynamism.

items.title: Fetal heart monitors still available online despite being banned
items.description: Home fetal doppler devices were banned from sale in Australia last year but they are still readily available for purchase online, prompting experts to issue warnings.

items.description: Much of Jackson "Jacko" Doolan's memory from December 14 is a blur, but there is one moment that remains crystal clear.

items.title: Republicans push to hold Clintons in contempt over Epstein probe
items.description: The Clintons are refusing to testify before a committee in the US House of Representatives, accusing Republicans of leading a weaponised process against them.

items.title: Trump's Board of Peace gains members ahead of Davos signing

featured_image.name: US President Donald Trump departs White House for World Economic Forum in Davos

items.description:
US President Donald Trump's newly created "Board of Peace" is gaining members while exposing rifts among Western nations, as the initiative designed to oversee Gaza's reconstruction expands into a broader conflict-resolution body that some fear could challenge the United Nations.

On Wednesday, divisions sharpened as Israel, Egypt, Bahrain, Azerbaijan, and Kosovo announced they would join the board, while Norway and Sweden followed France in declining the invitation. A White House official said about 30 countries are expected to sign on, with 50 having received invitations.[1][2]

Trump is scheduled to hold a formal signing ceremony Thursday at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, where the charter will be officially established.[3][4]

items.title: Trump drops Greenland tariffs threat as he heralds 'future deal' with NATO
items.description: Donald Trump says he has agreed to a "framework of a future deal" on Greenland after talks with NATO's secretary-general, and he will no longer impose tariffs on European nations that had opposed a US takeover.

items.title: City real estate prices on record rebound as million-dollar club grows
items.description: The Melbourne real estate market is leading a "decisive recovery", according to property portal Domain, as the city hits a four-year high for its median house price after strong growth across the country last year.

items.title: President Trump Announces U.S. Military Airstrike in Venezuela
items.description: President Trump states the U.S. military conducted its first known airstrike inside Venezuela targeting a dock where drugs were allegedly loaded onto boats[1][2][4].

items.title: Trump Meets Netanyahu at Mar-a-Lago for Gaza Ceasefire Phase Two Talks
items.description: President Trump met with Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu to discuss advancing phase two of the Gaza ceasefire, including reconstruction and responses to Iran[1][4].

items.title: Feds Launch Massive Taxpayer Fraud Probe in Minnesota After Viral Video
items.description: Federal agencies including DHS, FBI, and ICE investigate $110 million in suspected fraud at Minnesota child care centers following a viral YouTube video[3].

items.description: Public backlash against AI infrastructure data centers grows, with protests and demands for bans influencing Democratic Party strategies for future elections[3].

items.description: China prioritizes humanoid robots in tech race with U.S., ramping up production while warning of industry bubble and potential bottlenecks[3].

items.description: President Trump spoke with Putin amid ongoing Ukraine conflict, with Russia reevaluating peace plan tenets after Ukrainian denials[1].

items.title: Democratic Gubernatorial Candidates in Wisconsin Focus on Inflation and Trump
items.description: Seven Democrats vying for Wisconsin governor blame economic issues on Trump and emphasize affordability ahead of 2026 primary[3].
